content.description:
Students are asked to design an experiment to determine the molarity of a <math alttext="B a C l 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> solution. After examining the <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> values of some barium-containing compounds, the students decide to use <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 C O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to precipitate the barium ions. An excess of <math alttext="K 2 C O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is added to a <math alttext="50.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of the <math alttext="B a C l 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> solution, and the reaction represented by the following equation occurs.
<math alttext="B a C l 2, aqueous, plus K 2 C O 3, aqueous, react to produce B a C O 3, solid, plus 2 K C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><mi>BaCO</mi></mpadded><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>KCl</mi></mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>
The <math alttext="B a C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is filtered, dried, and weighed. The data are recorded in the following table.
 Volume of <math alttext="B a C l 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Volume of <math alttext="0.100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></math> <math alttext="K 2 C O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>CO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>Mass of <math alttext="B a C O 3, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math><math alttext="150 decimal point milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>150</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math><math alttext="1.97 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1.97</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math>
The molar masses of <math alttext="B a C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="B a C O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>BaCO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are <math alttext="208 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>208</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>mol</mi></math> and <math alttext="197 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>197</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>mol</mi></math>, respectively.
content.question: On the basis of the experimental data, what was <math alttext="the molar concentration of B a with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Ba</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mpadded></math> in the original <math alttext="50.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of the solution?

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
